Simple TCP Client

A simple packaged Chrome app and a tutorial on how to get started...

Download .zip Download .tar.gz View on GitHub

A step-wise tutorial for building a Chrome app
I created this app with just one purpose: to learn how to create a Chrome app. I needed a simple way to test the custom communication protocol of a TCP server running on a PIC32-based IoT device I was working on. There were, ofcourse, easier ways to do this but they wouldn't have been as much fun :-)

This application also supports sending pre-defined sequences over the network.

This project page contains a step-wise tutorial for building a Chrome app.

A great tutorial for building a packaged Chrome app is available in this Google Code Lab and I will be referring to quite a lot -- BUT -- I found the example code in that code lab a little complex for a complete n00b such as myself, so in case you feel the same way, I hope you find the following tutorial useful.

Step 4 - Creating a Simple Application

Previous Step: The Background Script (background.js)

Let's create an HTML file, "window.html", which will contain a text field, a button and a text area.

"window.html" is loaded in background.js in the "onLaunched" listener in following statement:

chrome.app.window.create('window.html',
                         {'bounds': {'width': 250, 'height': 250}});

Step 3 - The Background Script (background.js)

Previous Step: Creating the Manifest (manifest.json)

In the manifest.json we created in the previous step, we configured the following path for background.js:

{
    //..........
    //..........
    'app': {
        'background': {
        'scripts': ['js/background.js']
        }
    }
}

Create a folder "js" and create file background.js with the following content:

/**
 * 'onLaunched' listener
 */
chrome.app.runtime.onLaunched.addListener(function() {
    // We'll add more functionality later, for now we'll just create
    // the window with dimensions 250x250
    chrome.app.window.create('window.html',
                             {'bounds': {'width': 250, 'height': 250}});

});

This "listener" will be called when the application is launched, for now, all we are doing in this listener is creating the HTML view. For more details on a Chrome app's lifecycle, checkout this Google page or the following lifecycle diagram for quick reference:

Lifecycle Diagram from Google Chrome Developer portal

Now that we have the basic application framework setup, let's create a basic HTML view with some straight forward JavaScript in the next step to create a simple application.

To get the "sandbox" branch at this point, you can checkout the following commit (refer to this post if you need a quick reference to Git commands for doing this):

git checkout 0ee524052b0a58f7234d55f3c61875d0545bb3bf

Next Step: Creating a Simple Application

Step 2 - Creating the Manifest (manifest.json)

Previous Step: Getting Started

Creating a manifest is simple enough:

{
    'name': 'Sample Chrome App',
    'description': 'A simple chrome app to accompany the tutorial at http://schaazzz.github.io/simple_tcp_client/',
    'version': '0.1',
    'app': {
        'background': {
        'scripts': ['js/background.js']
        }
    }
}

You can download manifest.json or checkout the "sandbox" branch from the following commit (refer to this post if you need a quick reference to Git commands for doing this):

git checkout c5449c7d5c60b2e6eb946332ec34af8ee1b658df

Next Step: The Background Script (background.js)
